awd_titl_txt: Extending the Reach of Gravitational-Wave Detectors to Detect Post-Merger Signals from Binary Neutron Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research in relativity and relativistic astrophysics and it addresses the priority areas of NSF's "Windows on the Universe" Big Idea. Multi-messenger gravitational-wave (GW) astronomy has already shown itself capable of answering fundamental questions about the synthesis of heavy elements and the expansion rate of the Universe. New methods developed here will study the non-astrophysical noise sources, including earthquakes and Earth-wide magnetic fields, and remove those effects from the data. It will also make it possible to detect more neutron star and black hole mergers, in addition to GWs from other astrophysical sources such as exploding stars or the emission from a newly-born neutron star. This work will capitalize on the excitement of GW astronomy to build a new outreach program with a focus on GWs to Minneapolis and St. Paul. The group will use these activities to help students understand what LIGO is and how it detects GW signals in order to make this field accessible and available to a new generation of young scientists.

Multi-messenger gravitational-wave (GW) astronomy has arrived with the detection of the merger of compact binary systems. With Advanced LIGO and Advanced Virgo pushing towards design sensitivity, continued and new efforts to characterize the detectors and subtract known physical effects from the data is required. This work enables the possibility of detecting more compact binaries, as well as discoveries of GWs from other astrophysical sources. Along with the ongoing advances in instrumentation, the realization of GW astronomy depends critically on continued advances in data analysis capabilities. With the goal of significantly increasing the science reach of the advanced detectors, this project will develop techniques and lead searches with new observing run data. The improved search for long-duration burst GWs from compact binary mergers and other sources will increase our sensitivity to signals belonging to an astrophysically important sector of parameter space. Work on the identification and characterization of the seismic environments will increase the available observing time for the observatories, maximizing both their sensitivity and uptime. The new techniques for subtraction of non-linear signals illuminate all of the information that is possible to extract from the interferometer data, supporting understanding of the detector and increasing sensitivity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award has enabled the gravitational-wave group at the University of Minnesota to maximize multi-messenger science made possible by the worldwide network of gravitational-wave detectors, in particular with analysis of data from LIGO. The University of Minnesota team and its collaborators have three main goals: (i) develop techniques and lead searches for identifying unmodeled transients and use them to conduct searches with the ongoing gravitational-wave observing ones, (ii) develop techniques and lead infrastructure development for generating alerts for the broader follow-up community based on gravitational-wave data, and (iii) develop techniques to mitigate seismic and magnetic noise sources thereby reducing the effects of sources of poor data quality.


Over the past few years, the LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC) and Virgo collaborations have been developing searches that look for broad classes of transients with many second and longer time-scales. Traditionally there are two types of pipelines: one category targeting modeled signals and the other category tracking unmodeled events, both signals being predictions of General Relativity. The group helped to prepare the ongoing observing run's analyses for long-duration gravitational wave signals with unknown sky locations (the long-duration all-sky search), leading to the strongest limits to date on these sources from the previous observing run, and is now prepared to help deploy one of the algorithms partially developed at Minnesota on the data. This pipeline was used to search for magnetar flares, providing the strongest constraints yet on an unexplored region of parameter space. 


Our group develops software and mock data challenges designed to build and test the alert system for the gravitational-wave detectors. Rapid analysis of the gravitational-wave data in the era of the advanced detectors is done by online low-latency pipelines. We prepared a low-latency stream of data with dedicated software injection suites with which to test both the compact binary coalescence and unmodeled search pipelines, the enrichment infrastructure, and the alert pipeline used to report information to the external community. The real-time public data products aiding electromagnetic/neutrino follow-up of binary merger candidates include a variety of data products characterizing the event. We have been adding to the existing data products, including creation of a tool to predict electromagnetic counterparts based on the low-latency data products, both from the gravitational-wave searches at very low latency and parameter estimation on longer timescales.


We are also involved in detector characterization as applied to Advanced LIGO and Virgo, including the development and deployment of low-latency seismic monitors for measuring any source of ground motion that can couple into the interferometers. We built and deployed software (known as seismon) for the Earthquake Early Warning (EEW) systems. The seismic surface waves hinder the process of keeping the instrument at a linear operating point and often induce higher frequency noise by upconverting low-frequency optical motion. In addition, most detector characterization analyses have the limitation that only linearly coupled noise sources are measured and removed, which in fact are only a subset of the full dynamics of the detectors; a generic framework to determine arbitrary couplings in the interferometers would be useful to maximize their sensitivity, and therefore, it is worthwhile to extend these regression techniques to more complicated nonlinear couplings.  To address this, we built and deployed a machine-learning-based DeepClean algorithm to increase the sensitivity of the search by removing environmental contamination from the measured interferometer data. Looking forward, we expect this to lead to increased number of transient detections, reduced false alarms and improved inferences of astrophysical source parameters. 

We have also been able to provide research opportunities to students with interests in physics and statistics, and help to train them to become the next generation of scientists. We have also found that our students, including undergraduates, can be trained to become such effective researchers that they can actually make contributions to LIGO science that benefits the effort of the entire LSC. For our graduate students, there is exposure to the broad range of multi-messenger science that only a large experiment like LIGO can provide. As a result of this award, we have had three graduate students deeply involved in LIGO science, more than half a dozen undergraduates, and three high school students. At the intersection of LIGO and the data science program, our group is also supporting a K-12 outreach program in which we are developing activities related to data science and astrophysics for the students to take part in. Grade school students and teachers at Hamline Elementary School in St. Paul, MN have been and will continue to be exposed to the wonder and significance of LIGO’s research; this outreach creates significant excitement for science and physics.
